description: Chart and maps show changes, road closings and protests that will take place in New York City during Republican National Convention; chart; maps (M)
title: Getting Around (During) the Convention
title_page: Getting Around (During) the Convention - The New York Times
text:
Getting Into Manhattan
N.J. Transit -- All Midtown Direct service is rerouted to Hoboken, where customers can connect to PATH trains, N.Y. Waterway ferries, or N.J. Transit buses, all of which will honor N.J. Transit rail tickets. Northeast Corridor trains will experience delays while trains are searched at Newark or Secaucus. Use of overhead luggage racks will be prohibited, many restrooms will be locked, and onboard trash bins will be sealed. www.njtransit.com/nn--rnc--2.shtml
Long Island Rail Road -- Service is normal, but the railroad suggests that customers transfer to the subway at other terminals, such as Flatbush Avenue or Jamaica, to avoid pedestrian congestion at Penn Station. www.mta.info/lirr/RNC/Amtrak Service is normal, but all Northeast Corridor trains except Clocker and Keystone trains require reservations. www.amtrak.com/press/ad20040720000.html
Express Buses -- Manhattan-bound X17J, X22 and X31 buses travel on 42nd St. instead of 34th St. The X51 bus is re-routed at the exit of the Queens-Midtown Tunnel onto 37th St., returning to its regular route at 37th St. and Avenue of the Americas. www.mta.info/nyct/service/convention.htm
Around Madison Square Garden
Public access to Penn Station and Madison Square Garden will be through the Seventh Ave. entrance at 32nd St. and the subway entrance on 34th St. between Seventh and Eighth Aves. Other entrances will be closed to the public. Vehicles will be prohibited from 31st St. to 33rd St., Avenue of the Americas to Ninth Ave., at all times. While the convention is in session, Eighth Ave. will be closed from 23rd St. to 34th St., and Seventh Ave. from 42nd St. to 29th St. JAMES BRONZAN AND JOE BURGESS
